reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central element of the essay’s case for “no easy eutopia”: the claim in §3.3 that many plausible views become extremely fussy because even a tiny fraction of “bads” (e.g., 1 part in 10^22) can prevent a mostly-great future, combined with the essay’s general thesis that large-scale futures are fragile. If the critique succeeded, it would meaningfully shift the essay from “mostly-great futures are rare without steering” toward “mostly-great futures are effectively impossible at scale under adversarial threat,” which also undercuts the essay’s closing attempt to separate ‘narrow target’ from ‘unlikely to hit it’. 

However, the strength is only moderate. The critique assumes (i) that “bads” in the separate-aggregation model are naturally triggered by security compromises/adversaries, (ii) that compromise probability per star system is bounded away from zero and roughly independent, and (iii) that any compromise constitutes enough “bad” to count as the relevant kind of moral bad in §3.3. Those are plausible threat-model intuitions but not established by the essay’s framework; the essay’s “bads” could be narrower (e.g., severe suffering) or mitigable by compartmentalization, redundancy, moral circle expansion, etc. The critique also somewhat conflates §2’s ‘moral error’ discussion with ‘active adversary’ failure modes; while related via Goodhart/attack surface, it’s not directly argued in the position. 

Correctness is mixed: it’s broadly right that at large scales, nonzero per-unit failure rates can make ‘zero bads anywhere’ standards effectively unattainable, and that this interacts sharply with the essay’s 10^22 toy calculation. But it overstates when it says the paper “accidentally proves” inevitability/impossibility and that scaling “inevitably disqualifies” a future; that conclusion depends on additional probabilistic and normative premises not provided. Clarity is high: the mechanism and claimed implication are easy to pin down. Dead weight is low, and it’s essentially a single focused issue. Overall, because it’s an insightful but premise-sensitive extension rather than a direct refutation of the essay’s argument, it poses a moderate challenge but not a decisive one.
title: Adversarial threats at galactic scale make "no bads" criteria impossible to satisfy
